Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to determine how the dry sliding wear behavior and wear mechanisms of a range of recently-discovered, very high strength, nanostructured FeNiMnAl spinodal alloys vary with changes in microstructure such as phase size and composition. Testing will be performed at a range of speeds in air, argon and oxygen in order to understand the effects of local heating and of oxidation, including the role played by wear debris. The project will utilize a range of state-of-the-art techniques to characterize the pre- and post- wear specimens including transmission electron microscopy (TEM) coupled with X-ray spectroscopy; profilometry; X-ray diffraction; nanoindentation; cross-sectional scanning electron microscopy, and atom probe tomography (APT). The observed wear behavior will be modeled. The work will involve several collaborations: alloys will be drop cast at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL) by Dr. Easo George; high temperature wear experiments will be carried out at the ORNL Tribology Research User Center in collaboration with Dr. Peter J. Blau; APT will be performed at ORNL with the aid of Dr. Mike K. Miller; and focused ion beam cross-sectioning/TEM will be performed with the aid of Professor Paul Munroe of the University of New South Wales, Australia.

If successful, the project will not only provide an understanding of the relationship between the microstructure, deformation processes and the wear behavior of FeNiMnAl spinodal alloys, leading to their possible commercial utilization, but will contribute to understanding the wear behavior of spinodal alloys as a class of materials, which have been little studied. It will also lead to the development of cutting edge techniques to study wear. The project will train both a Ph.D. student and several undergraduates. The results will be published in refereed journals and presented at various conferences.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Fe30Ni20Mn25Al25 is an alloy system made up of four elements. From the microscopic view, this alloy has two kinds of layer aligned alternatively, just like Oreo cookies. One layer is rich in iron and manganese, while the other is rich in nickel and aluminum. Due to the interesting microstructure, this alloy has many amazing properties, such as remarkably high yield strength. Since this alloy could have many potential applications, it is important to determine how good the wear resistance of this recently discovered material is. In this project, wear tests at different conditions were conducted and a combination of state-of-the-art techniques were used, such as scanning electron microscopy (SEM), X-ray diffraction and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) to characterize the wear behavior.

In this project, pin-on-disk wear tests of Fe30Ni20Mn25Al25 were conducted. The Fe30Ni20Mn25Al25 was made into a pin which is bullet-shaped. Either 347 stainless steel (SS347) or yttria-stabilized zirconia (YSZ) was used for the counterface disk.

It was found the wear of the Fe30Ni20Mn25Al25 was much more severe at room temperature than at elevated temperature. The surface of the Fe30Ni20Mn25Al25 after the room-temperature wear test was much smoother than that after the elevated temperature wear test. Mechanically-mixed layers (layers mixed of materials from both pin and disk) formed on the worn pins during both room-temperature and elevated temperature wear tests. Oxidation played an important role in the process of the elevated temperature wear tests. Additionally, both two-body and three-body wear took place during both the room-temperature and elevated temperature wear tests.

In order to evaluate the effect of the sliding velocity, pin-on-disk wear tests of Fe30Ni20Mn25Al25 were conducted in air at room temperature at different sliding velocities. When the counterface disk was YSZ, the wear of the Fe30Ni20Mn25Al25 pin for low sliding velocity wear tests (0.1 m·s-1, 0.25 m·s-1) was much more severe than high sliding velocity wear tests (0.5 m·s-1, 0.75 m·s-1, 1 m·s-1). Oxidation resulting from high contact surface temperatures played an important role in the wear process during the high sliding velocity wear tests. At higher sliding velocity, YSZ underwent a crystal structure tranformation, which can make the disk be easier to deform. When the counterface disk was SS347, the wear of the Fe30Ni20Mn25Al25 pin in wear tests at 0.1 m·s-1 and 0.25 m·s-1 was much more severe than that in the wear tests at 0.5 m·s-1, 0.75 m·s-1 and 1 m·s-1. Oxidation was also much more severe in the wear tests at sliding velocity of 0.5 m·s-1 or above. The oxide provided some protection to the pin and decreased the wear rates.

The effect of the third bodies produced in the wear tests was also studied by conducting wear tests with or without the removal of the wear debris. The wear of the Fe30Ni20Mn25Al25 pin was much more severe with the removal of the debris during the wear test. The oxidation occurred during the wear test and the oxide debris produced in the wear test formed a mechanically-mixed layer, which provided protection to the pin and decreased the wear rate.


Last Modified: 04/08/2016
Modified by: Ian Baker
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Fe30Ni20Mn25Al25 is an alloy system made up of four elements. From the microscopic view, this alloy has two kinds of layer aligned alternatively, just like Oreo cookies. One layer is rich in iron and manganese, while the other is rich in nickel and aluminum. Due to the interesting microstructure, this alloy has many amazing properties, such as remarkably high yield strength. Since this alloy could have many potential applications, it is important to determine how good the wear resistance of this recently discovered material is. In this project, wear tests at different conditions were conducted and a combination of state-of-the-art techniques were used, such as scanning electron microscopy (SEM), X-ray diffraction and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) to characterize the wear behavior. In this project, pin-on-disk wear tests of Fe30Ni20Mn25Al25 were conducted. The Fe30Ni20Mn25Al25 was made into a pin which is bullet-shaped. Either 347 stainless steel (SS347) or yttria-stabilized zirconia (YSZ) was used for the counterface disk. When the counterface disk was SS347, the wear of the Fe30Ni20Mn25Al25 pin in wear tests at 0.1 m·s-1 and 0.25 m·s-1 was much more severe than that in the wear tests at 0.5 m·s-1, 0.75 m·s-1 and 1 m·s-1. The oxidation occurred during the wear test and the oxide debris produced in the wear test formed a mechanically-mixed layer, which provided protection to the pin and decreased the wear rate.
